awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: Bearingless Electric Motors for Industrial Compressor Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of new technology that produces completely integrated electric machines.  These machines will leverage geometry not readily manufactured with conventional machining to support 3-dimensional flux paths and actuate across all six degrees of freedom. This project's bearingless technology can unlock customer gains through enhanced system sensing capability to enable predictive maintenance and decreased noise, vibration, and harshness. The value proposition of bearingless technology is particularly strong for turbomachinery applications in wastewater aeration, waste heat recovery, automotive turbocharges, and thermal grid storage. By eliminating bearings, the proposed technology can increase the mean time between failure of motor systems. Through increased system reliability and lifetime, this technology can accelerate deployment of highly efficient, sustainable, and intelligent infrastructure solutions for the benefit of society.

This I-Corps project is based on the development of new bearingless electric motor generator technology that provides the benefits of magnetic levitation while solving the challenges associated with magnetic bearings. The mechanical bearings used to support the shaft of today's electric motors and generators are a source of major pain for integrators, owners, and operators of electric machines. These pain points primarily come in the form of low system reliability and high total cost of ownership. While magnetic bearing manufacturers have attempted to solve these pain points by magnetically levitating the shaft (thereby eliminating mechanical bearings from motor/generators), this solution has seen limited market acceptance due to increased capital cost, lengthy timelines for new product commissioning, and integration challenges. This project's bearingless motor technology integrates the functionality of a magnetic bearing into the existing hardware of an electric motor/generator. While conventional electric motor/generators use stator winding current to control electromagnetic torque on their rotor, this bearingless motor/generators additionally use stator current to control electromagnetic forces on the rotor that make the motor act as if it were also a magnetic bearing. This technology is employed by unlocking the large radial electromagnetic pressure that is present in today's electric motor/generators but is canceled by deliberate design symmetry.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Mechanical bearings used in today’s motors and generators are the most problematic component of industrial motor systems, where high uptime and efficiency are needed. It is estimated that 40-60% of all motor system failures are due to bearings and most industrial motor system maintenance requirements pertain to prolonging bearing lifetime. The US Department of Energy (DOE) estimates that 20% of US electric energy is consumed by industrial compressor systems, with 30-80% of this energy being wasted in throttles. Successful deployment of variable speed motor drives (VSDs) can nearly eliminate throttle losses. However, VSDs significantly reduce bearing lifetime, with a 60% reduction of mean time between failure reported in a survey of installed motor systems. Bearing lifetime concerns are a primary reason for hesitancy in adopting VSDs and the US DOE indicates that VSD penetration levels have remained at under 10% across the industrial sector. The team’s bearingless machine technology solves these challenges. Successful adaptation of our solution will reduce US electric energy consumption by up to 9%.

Magnetically levitated rotors offer a compelling value proposition to motor systems through significant improvements in lifetime, reliability, and controllable rotor dynamics: noise, vibration, and harshness while also eliminating oil from the system. Conventional product approaches to magnetically levitated motors present shortcomings that have limited their commercial success. Active magnetic bearing force actuators significantly increase size, cost, and are difficult to integrate, and legacy bearingless technology results in low performance (low efficiency, low power density, and high cost) machines that are untenable for industrial systems of significant power ratings. The team has developed innovations that provide new approaches to magnetically levitating rotors which solve the aforementioned shortcomings.

The I-CORPS team interviewed stakeholders across broad turbomachinery markets to understand their electric motor and bearing needs and determine if the team’s technology can provide a solution. The team discovered growing demand for oil-free bearing systems, particularly within custom turbomachinery and the heating ventilation and air condition (HVAC) markets. Current products in these spaces encompass magnetic and air bearing technologies, with stakeholders reporting acute pain points with both types of products. The interviews revealed that today’s oil-free bearing solutions are a limiting factor in product development and in turbomachinery manufacturers’ ability to reach new markets. From the interviews, the team identified challenges and pathways to adapt their technology innovations into oil-free bearing solutions. High priority markets identified included a beachhead market consisting of customers with compelling immediate needs that create a suitable risk profile to enable the adaptation of new motor and bearing solutions into their products as well as a larger, more risk-adverse market that can provide a large-scale opportunity for adaptation for the team’s solution once it is successfully used by customers in the beachhead market.

 


Last Modified: 03/13/2025
Modified by: Giri Venkataramanan
